Award.AbstractNarration:
Communication and transportation networks provide the infrastructure for life in modern society. Whether messaging over the Internet, making voice or video calls, or choosing between routes on highways, the quality of one's experience depends critically on the design and control of such networks. A major concern of much of the research on networks has been congestion; in particular the congestion resulting from the negative impact of decentralized decisions on social welfare. This literature has shown that autonomous, self-interested users can experience increased costs or substantial losses in efficiency (e.g., delays in traffic) compared with socially optimal outcomes due to congestion in networks. Of course, not all decision making in decentralized networks gives rise to negative externalities. In fact, network industries are often characterized as those that have increasing returns to scale. Consider, for example, telephones or fax machines. The value of these technologies increases in the number of users who have adopted them; similarly, the value of computer software increases as more users purchase this technology.

In a departure from previous experimental research, we propose studying interactive decision behavior in networks, where choices result in positive externalities; where the utility that a given agent derives from her choice increases in the number of other users making the same choice. We are interested in a family of applications regarding public modes of transportation where agents, sharing the same route from a common origin to common destination, can also share part of the cost. We propose to conduct several laboratory experiments which differ in (i) the cost associated with alternative modes of transportation, (ii) the homogeneity or heterogeneity of the players, (iii) the information available to the players about previous decisions of other players, and (iv) whether decisions are made in a simultaneous or sequential manner. The research proposed is one of the first systematic studies that investigate cost-sharing of public transportation by independent, autonomous agents. We propose a novel approach to cost-sharing allocation in a dynamic setting that integrates both theory and experimentation. The examination of heterogeneity in users, the information that they have of one another, and issues such as segment capacity, all bear important implications for policy making related to network traffic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An important question in economics, transportation, and computer science is how the cost or reward from a joint investment is shared in a fair and efficient manner. In transportation research, cost sharing can be studied in the context of ridesharing, where individual travelers can decide to drive solo, share a vehicle (carpooling) or take public transportation. A central issue in ridesharing is that the sharing of cost implies positive externalities and hence coordination problems for users. Investigations on ridesharing have become especially timely with the recent growth in ridesharing businesses such as Uber and Lyft.

Using experimental methods, our research examined cost-sharing in transportation networks, where commuters (human subjects) had to independently choose one of several modes of private or public transportation, where the commonly known costs of transportation were shared with the other users. This program of research is one of the first aimed at studying decentralized decision behavior in networks that are not susceptible to congestion. To date, our research on ridesharing, funded by the National Science Foundation, has resulted in five peer-reviewed journal articles, one book chapter, one research monograph, and eleven conference presentations.

Focusing on repeated, rather than static games, an important contribution of our research has been the construction and testing of adaptive learning models to account for how decisions evolved over time. In addition, our investigations of the impact of the heterogeneity of the users, information structure, and local, rather than global, centralization of their decisions are other, novel contributions of the research. The major accomplishment of our research activity is an innovative approach to cost-sharing in a dynamic setting that integrates theory and experimentation. Our findings provide strong support for the descriptive power of the equilibrium solution, even in situations where the price of anarchy is rather high, in comparison to the maximization of social welfare.

Because our research was guided by real issues in transportation and communication, our conclusions could guide management in constructing or modifying alternative modes of public transportation for cost-sharing travel, and firms developing new on-line software for regulating traffic and enhancing communication among commuters. For example, the construction of special traffic lanes for shared riding and the investment in additional public transportation could result from the systematic study of commuter behavior under alternative assumptions about the population size, the information provided to the commuters, and the opportunities offered to them with modern technology to coordinate their choices. With new software for traffic regulation and route choice (e.g., GPS, Waze), we hope that our program of research will have additional impacts.
